intro: Phacelia argillacea, commonly known as clay phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in clay soils and is often found in meadows and open woodlands. It has a short growing season and is known for its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Phacelia argillacea is also used in ecological restoration projects due to its hardy nature and ability to stabilize soil.
